author: {'steamid': '76561198276634938', 'num_games_owned': 10153, 'num_reviews': 1500, 'playtime_forever': 1421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1421, 'last_played': 1676952039}
review:
我不敢相信會發生這種事。 《獅身人面像》是我在GameCube上最喜歡的遊戲之一，10多年後我終於可以再次玩了。

只需要978 MB的空間。 考慮到它的年齡，它看起來很棒。 消除混疊。 60幀/秒。 它很便宜，現在還在讓利。 為什麼埠不能總是這樣？

根據Steam論壇的消息，許多錯誤已經修復，開發者將添加正確的金鑰映射，並修復人們現在抱怨的其他問題（視窗模式、1440p支持等）。

到目前為止，我只打了一個小時，但由於當時這是一場偉大的比賽，而且這將是一個偉大的港口，我明確推薦它。

展示您對經典遊戲優秀埠的支持！ 在噴射機電臺、塔斯馬尼亞虎泰和獅身人面像之後，我們可能會有一些偉大的事情發生。

更新：

顯然，破窗模式已經修復。 開發人員正在積極與社區溝通，尤其是在科技問題上。 豎起大拇指。

更新2:

開發人員（是的，這個埠實際上是由一個人完成的）幾乎每天都會推送修補程式。 未完成的測試版關卡（包括全新世界）將作為免費DLC發佈，可能由MODDER完成。 夥計們，支持！

author: {'steamid': '76561197998543056', 'num_games_owned': 2354, 'num_reviews': 642, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1619800729}
review:
[b] > Step into the sandals of Sphinx, the sassiest hero this side of the Nile, and Tutankhamun, the mummy with more swag than a sarcophagus at a disco party! 🕺🔥
> 
> Sphinx, the human-cat hybrid, got moves smoother than a snake in the desert. Combat feels like a graceful dance, and I'm over here wondering if Sphinx took lessons from ancient Egyptian ninjas. His swordplay is so satisfying, it's like cutting through a perfectly baked baklava. 🗡️🍰
> 
> Then there's Tutankhamun, our chill mummy buddy. Stealth sections got me feeling like I'm pulling off the greatest bandage heist in history. Sneaking around like a mummy ninja, avoiding enemies with the finesse of a professional hide-and-seek champion. 💀👻
> 
> Tutankhamun, the living crash test dummy, has more tricks up his mummified sleeves than a magician at a sarcophagus-themed party! 🎩✨
> 
> The atmosphere in this game is thicker than the hieroglyphs on a pyramid wall. The devs crafted a world so immersive, I half expected to find a hidden stash of ancient memes. The ambient music? It's like the ancient Egyptians hired Hans Zimmer to score their everyday lives. 🎶🏰
> 
> World design is on point. Exploring feels like I stumbled upon the Lost City of Gold but with more puzzles and less conquistadors. Each area is a tapestry of Egyptian history and mythology, and I'm here for it like a pharaoh at a pyramid unveiling. 🏞️🏛️
> 
> The puzzles! Oh, the puzzles! They're more intricate than a cat trying to figure out why the laser dot disappeared. Solving them makes me feel smarter than Thoth, the god of wisdom himself. Sphinx ain't just slashing swords; he's slashing through my self-doubt too. 🧠🔍
> 
> Exploration is like a treasure hunt through a time capsule. Finding hidden rooms and secret passages got me feeling like Lara Croft with an Egyptian flair. I'm raiding tombs with such enthusiasm; even Indiana Jones would be like, "Slow down, Sphinx, leave some for the rest of us!" 🕵️‍♀️🏺
[/b]

INT. VENTURE TOWER - NIGHT Lacroix, Beckett, Strauss, Isaac, Velvet, Jeanette, Gary, Tung, Jack, Nines, and Damsel are gathered in Lacroix's opulent office. A massive screen flickers to life, revealing Lacroix with a game controller in hand. 🌃🎮

LACROIX (trying to sound cool) Ah, my esteemed associates, gather 'round. Tonight, I present to you a masterpiece of gaming - Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy. 🕹️🔥

The group exchanges skeptical glances, but Lacroix presses play. 👀🎮

BECKETT (grinning) Well, well, Lacroix. I never thought I'd see the night when the Prince himself indulges in video games. What's next, karaoke? 🎤😂

LACROIX (dismissive) This is merely a momentary diversion. I have an appreciation for ancient artifacts, even in pixelated form. The game starts, and Sphinx appears on the screen. 🎮🏛️

ISAAC (raising an eyebrow) And who's this fine feline fellow? Your long-lost ancestor, Lacroix? 🐱🤨

LACROIX (ignoring the comment) This is Sphinx, our daring protagonist. Swift as a Nosferatu in the shadows. 🦇🌑

VELVET (smirking) More like swift as a Malkavian on a particularly cryptic rant. Laughter ripples through the group. 😜🤣

JEANETTE (teasing) Oh, Sphinx, the charming cat-man. Reminds me of someone I once knew. Except, of course, without the allure. 😻💋

LACROIX (looking unamused) Watch and learn. There's more to this game than meets the eye. 👀📖

GARY (raising an eyebrow) Lacroix, my man, you're playing like a Tremere trying to grasp the concept of subtlety. 🤔🧛‍♂️

LACROIX (annoyed) I assure you, my skills are unparalleled. Meanwhile, Sphinx is struggling with a puzzle. 🧩😅

TUNG (laughing) Even I could handle that puzzle better, and English isn't even my first language! 😂🌍

LACROIX (grumbling) Enough banter. This game requires strategy and finesse. Sphinx encounters a boss, and Lacroix faces a virtual defeat. 😤👾

STRAUSS (dryly) It appears that even in the digital realm, your plans crumble, Lacroix. The group bursts into laughter as Lacroix scowls at the screen. 😆🤣

VELVET (smirking) I must say, Lacroix, your virtual escapades are more entertaining than a night at The Asylum. 😈🎭

NINES (chuckles) Who knew the Prince had a soft spot for ancient cat-themed adventures? 😼😄

JACK (snickering) You're making our vampire overlord look like a fledgling trying to grasp undead reality. 😂🧛‍♂️

JEANETTE (playfully) Lacroix, darling, if only ruling a city was as easy as navigating this game. 🏙️🕹️

DAMSEL (rolling her eyes) Typical. The Prince can't even navigate a simple pitfall. No wonder our city's a mess. 🤦‍♀️🕳️

As the game continues, the banter intensifies, creating a night of camaraderie and laughter in the most unexpected of places - Lacroix's office. 🌃😂🎉

LACROIX (grinning) Well, my dear colleagues, while I may have faced a few setbacks in the digital realm, I must admit that Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy offers a refreshing diversion from the nightly politics. 🌌🕹️

BECKETT (smirking) So, are you saying you enjoyed getting your pixels handed to you?

LACROIX (nodding) Indeed. It's a testament to the game's challenge, a puzzle in itself. Much like ruling a city, wouldn't you agree? 🧩🌃

STRAUSS (inclining his head) An intriguing parallel, Prince Lacroix. The dynamics of power, even in a virtual landscape, are quite captivating.

LACROIX (raising an eyebrow) Precisely, Herr Strauss. Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy provides a unique blend of strategy and entertainment, much like orchestrating the delicate dance of Kindred society. 🩸💃

JEANETTE (grinning) Well, I never thought I'd see the day when our stoic Prince would find joy in a game. Perhaps there's hope for you yet, cherie.

LACROIX (smirking) Hope, dear Jeanette, is a rare commodity in our world. Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy, however, managed to deliver it in spades, even if it was virtual. 🃏🎭

The group looks at Lacroix, a mix of surprise and amusement on their faces.

LACROIX (leaning back) In conclusion, this game, with its intricate puzzles and unexpected challenges, has proven to be a worthy diversion. A brief respite from the eternal night we navigate. 🌙🎮

As the room falls into contemplative silence, they continue watching Lacroix navigate the virtual world, forging an unlikely bond through the shared experience of Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy. 🕹️🌃

author: {'steamid': '76561198145534128', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1053, 'last_played': 1702041007}
review:
The main character is an EXOTIC CATBOY wearing EYELINER and JEWELRY, a CROP TOP, has CHISELED ABS, and TIGHT LEATHER PANTS. This game is 20 YEARS OLD are the creators feckle gods who knew that look was gonna be peak thirst in two decades??

Anyway, beloved childhood game, unlike other childhood games it holds up insanely well. Graphics are fantastic, combat is much harder than I expected (it's not "The Dark Souls of 3D Zelda-esque!!" but you'll probably game over a few times), the puzzles are pretty fun especially with the mummy. You might have to resort to a walkthrough occasionally if you're as oblivious to obvious clues as me. Awesome game even if you don't have a nostalgia bias. Highly recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044565944', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1696714344}
review: This game has one quirk: it just isn't fun. The platforming is horrid, the collision detection is horrid. But worst of all is the huge distance between save points, make one wrong move (likely related to the aformentioned issues) and it's all the way back to re-do huge sections of the game. Even for it's time on the original Xbox this was a bottom tier game, I had hoped the remaster would make it better: it didn't.
developer_response:
After today's Steam update the game should have two new save statues at critical «ragequit» spots, with maybe more to come; just before the caged spider fight after picking up the Blade of Osiris (in the Uruk intro) as well as just before the Wall Section II entrance (at Heliopolis).

Keep in mind that editing maps from a 20-year-old game is a delicate business, so I try to be conservative here. If I start changing too much players will also complain about not having the original experience they like and remember. So it isn't easy to please everyone. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

author: {'steamid': '76561198046965786', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1695864025}
review: Honestly, the quest menu music alone is worth like 10% of the game. It is a "remaster" since the base game is still very much gamecube. But much higher resolution. Emulation basically, without the second layer hit in performance. Even my lattepanda 3 delta can run this game. Though, the shimmer effects do tank it's FPS. But its a  celeron N5105 with UHD graphics
developer_response:
Hi there, the game was fully ported to Windows, Linux and macOS and runs natively with the same original game engine Eurocom created in 2002 for Sphinx, called EngineX. No emulation involved, and yeah, gameplay code is the same.

Graphics, input, sound and more parts ended up being rewritten almost from scratch based on the internal and incomplete Windows version Eurocom had for dev and testing, that only ran with a few fake PS2-style gamepads they had around, with many effects and parts missing. 

I have had to re-implement, retrofit and oil up a lot of components, as well as make it work on 64-bit computers, which was another odyssey. All in all, a very fun "job" that the good people at THQ Nordic allowed since early 2017, and things are still improving at the moment. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198117115477', 'num_games_owned': 722, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1002, 'last_played': 1691687456}
review:
Оценка 6/10

Заинтересовался игрой супер давно, но она не оправдала моих ожиданий, ждал легкую адвенчуру, а получил местами очень душный геймплей, скучные загадки и посредственный сюжет.

Хочется отметить хорошую музыку и визуал, это прям да, сильная сторона игры.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045226937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 1013, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1013, 'last_played': 1692681684}
review:
Do you know what it means to "geld" something?

	I feel like a fucking fossil, but I need to tell the zoomers reading, before every game tried to be a Dark Souls clone, a similar trend was to try to make every game a Zelda clone. These are adventure games with varied but necessary inventories to give players the illusion of power and choice, when there's actually a fairly strict progression that's expected to be followed. For my money, the best titles in this "knock-off" genre are Pitfall: The Lost Expedition, and 3D Dot Game Heroes.

	What sets Zelda-like apart from actual Legend of Zelda games (at least, before BOTW) is that real Zelda games tend to be obsessively focused and exhaustive. I mean, even with how much the 3D entries' exploration made full use of those 3D environments, they didn't even bother to include a real "jump" button; When Nintendo wanted you to leap across a certain location, they had to give you enough room for a running start. When they wanted you to go up, they'd give you things to climb, elevators and air currents to ride, things that didn't need a dedicated "jump" button. So, if that's how much attention they could give to NOT binding one function to a whole-ass button, it's no wonder that those games often feel so full and fleshed-out.

	Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy, on the other hand, is endemic merely of the Zelda-like. You've got unique tools that are needed only a couple of times, and then, never again. They make up a rebindable inventory that's not really big enough to justify rebinding. You use these things to explore a world which, while massive, much of the promotional material and "making of" shows was cut down significantly from what could have been. Every time something looks like it's going somewhere, the game reins you back and pushes you in another direction that, while still entertaining, usually doesn't go far enough.

	This type of constraint is most pronounced in the flow of the story. It starts off okay, slowly opening up as wrong turn after wrong turn gives excuses to explore a little further in new directions. Things lose cohesion, though, as the story plods along a tired path that doesn't do anything very creative. (Young apprentice, jealousy and betrayal, chosen one, yadda yadda yadda.) Characters are introduced, and then sort of fade into obscurity if they aren't killed outright. Especially toward the end of the game, the plot feels rushed, like someone just ran out of time, and strung things together with the thinnest possible threads. With some of these bosses, I really felt like I didn't know who I was fighting, with a bare-bones explanation of why. To top it all off, as a final insult, it concludes with the stupidest, most abrupt cliffhanger ending one could possibly write. I wish that the parts that either felt so shoehorned or under-explained had showed up earlier, to not only give themselves more relevance, but to provide reasons for a little more variety and length.

	Speaking of variety and length...

	On a gameplay level, Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy is generally fun, but fleeting. It divides into two types: the open-world Zelda-type game with Sphinx, and Tutankhamen's stealth-driven linear stages that culminate in platforming and lever puzzles.
	With Sphinx, it sometimes seems like it's just moving you onto the next ability or item as soon as possible, which sounds good, but that means you're rarely exploring their real potential. You CAN use acid darts to melt chains anywhere (not just in the dungeon you're told to go to after you receive them), ice darts to freeze several types of enemies (not just in the dungeon where you get them), and captured Slim Burbles as a weapon (instead of just as a general bomb tool for blowing up rocks and shit.) Most of the items you get have multiple possible applications, but the game rarely uses them after their dedicated introductions. To that end, a lot of the equipment ends up feeling useless in the long run. It's like buying a new game, playing it once or twice, and then letting it rot on your shelf.
	In contrast, Tut's isolated levels often feel like they're combining unlocked abilities for the sake of building more complex puzzles and stealth segments. The irony is that the more restrictive design actually makes these sections feel fuller. I never spent as much time in these parts thinking about what could have been as I did in the rest of the game.
	So, I need to ask, were more intricate puzzles really not an option for the open world, where the player spends far more time? With so much space to work with, I figure that that would be the best opportunity to pack some of the locations choc-full of brain teasers. It just doesn't, though.

	To try and cover for the emptiness, Sphinx will try to keep you captivated by the style. When I first played this on the Gamecube, it looked pretty weird coming at me through a fucked-up CRT TV that I bought at a garage sale, with overemphasized greens and reds, and some weird kind of astigmatism effect. This having an Egypt theme, a lotta shit is red, and a lotta shit glows, and I'm glad that I've now gotten to fully appreciate its style through a better resolution on a clearer screen. (On a side note, I did encounter some spazzing light effects here and there, and some texture popping. There was also an occasional audio glitch where the music would stop playing for no real reason, but this is probably just my own hardware issue, because I'm playing this on an abacus. It's an acceptable trade-off for being able to change the FOV.)

	This is a pretty good looking game, even nearly twenty years removed. The character and enemy designs are just cartoony enough to not let them be taken too seriously, appropriately speaking in Zelda-like grunts and squawks, and some of the locations they populate are downright beautiful: a sprawling desert that crawls right up to a looong shoreline, a city built on top of electrified water, a bigass wall that makes the USA-Mexico border fence look like it's made outta fucking popsicle sticks, an imposing castle that looms threateningly over a volcanic wasteland. There are quite a few impressive settings that nonetheless manage to fall under the umbrella of its Egyptian theme, and many are pulled off perfectly. For when this game originally came out, the combination of scale and detail is still impressive to this day.

	Yet, in spite of its physical size, it all feels minuscule due to its lack of depth. The puzzles for Sphinx are few and simple because most of them exist as tutorials for his equipment, which is itself such a small assortment that it will never be competing for space on your controller (unless you feel like binding captured creatures to your buttons. Again, that's not really necessary.)
	The soundtrack is memorable, and I like it, but it's quite repetitive. You're gonna hear the same pieces of music over and over.
	Being able to capture almost every land-dwelling non-boss monster after wearing them down, and use the collected enemies for your own purposes, à la Pokémon, is cool. However, this cornucopia of potential is damn near empty. Only a couple of caught enemies have any use for puzzles or combat, while the rest basically exist for the sake of being collected.
	This game could have used more of everything. A more cohesive plot, a few more puzzles and locations, a few more tools, and a few more types of enemies is all it would've taken to make it great.

	As it stands, Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy is the archetypal gelded 3D Zelda-like, something that could have been much more, but instead played it safe. I'd love to see a sequel, but I doubt it's gonna happen. I wish I had the patience to learn the authoring tools for this release, because I think that's where most of the potential for this game now lies. Oh, well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198150452720', 'num_games_owned': 547, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 1267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1267, 'last_played': 1625261105}
review:
I grew up playing this so I like it more than it reasonably deserves, but this game is still great.

The separation of two protagonists makes this game very unique from most other action games. The game has some very traditional powerups, like lightning and fire, but spoiler: You are just literally on fire or being electructed or crushed paper thin. One of the protagonists is dead and so he can just be horribly tortured and keep moving. The music and setting really stand out and the amount of content cut from it's early development is actually insane.

Basically, Egyptian Zelda goes hard.

review: I had fond memories of this game back on PS2. I can acknowledge the game's faults, especially the infamous ending, but I still love the experience. It's a game that fits the formula that the Legend of Zelda series has long since established, while still being original where it counts. And who can't help but love that Egyptian aesthetic, right? This was worth picking up, and 100%ing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068957488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 539, 'last_played': 1613865987}
review:
J'y jouais étant gosse, et il n'a pas trop mal vieillit.

Concrètement, le jeu est un Zelda avec la mythologie égyptienne.
Bon, allons un peu plus loin dans la critique: c'est un jeu qui se déroule en monde ouvert mais dans lequel on va devoir explorer des donjons à l'intérieur desquels, en général, on trouvera un objet nous permettant de progresser dans l'aventure. Les combats sont pas trop mal (pour un jeu sorti sur ps2): une épée avec un combo simple, un bouclier pour se protéger par la suite et ça sera tout.
Mais, il existe une subtilité: le jeu nous permet d'incarner à tour de rôle deux personnages (nous ne sommes pas libre de choisir quand l'on passe de l'un à l'autre). Et le deuxième personnage a un gameplay axé sur les énigmes et pas sur les combats, offrant un peu de variété mais cassant le rythme du jeu.

Bref si vous voulez un peu la nostalgie d'un Zelda de l'époque gamecube-wii avec plus de plateforme, mais qui sépare quand même assez nettement les phases de combat et d'énigme, ce jeu n'est vraiment pas mal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145307464', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1682615954}
review:
Este é o meu primeiro jogo de PS2, comprei no mesmo dia que o console lá em 2008 e foi um jogo que me surpreendeu mesmo naquela época e me prendeu por muito tempo, cheio de puzzles e com um inclusive que eu demorei anos pra conseguir resolver kkkkk

Ele tem uma jogabilidade que envelheceu bem
Os gráficos eram ótimos pra época e ainda continuam agradaveis hoje em dia
Não posso comentar muito da lore pq na época eu era criança e não entendia inglês 

Mas posso garantir que é um jogo que vale muitoa a pena ser jogado

author: {'steamid': '76561198857516375', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1066, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 933, 'last_played': 1703260085}
review: Bien que ce jeu soit sortis il y a longtemps (en 2003) ce jeu reste pour moi un jeu d'aventure absolument génial alternant entre le sérieux du personnage principal et l'ambiance plus relâchée et drôle de la momie. Les musiques sont très cools pour l'époque et les graphismes sont à la hauteur de ce qu'on pourrait espérer des jeux de cette année, voire plus encore. Pour ceux à la recherche de jeu d'aventure solo je recommande évidemment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198948245017', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 1130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1130, 'last_played': 1677697131}
review:
Got this game thinking I would get a jak and daxter but I ended up with a legend of zelda.

The explorations and dungeons are very fun but the dungeons themselves are extremely short. And the mummy sections feel tacked on despite being the most fun of the game (also extremely short) but sincerely when this game is doing puzzles it's doing what it does best.

Sadly the combat is not good at all and that extends to the bosses that are really boring. 

And finaly the story is basic but fun, the pantomimes that all characters do to compensate for the lack of voice acting is great though if they are too cartoony for a some what serious game is up to you to decide. The ending though, it left a cliff hanger through a serious cop out, if the last 10 seconds of the story didn't exist I'm sure I would be completely satisfied from what I got from this game now I'm kinda bummed that there is a small little kink that will never get resolved on the story (and it was one I was really interested in to leave the cherry on top). 

TL;DR: good exploration and puzzles, bad combat and bosses, buy if you aren't bothered by cliffhangers that will never get resolved.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007816119', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1677507078}
review: I played this game as a kid but nostalgia wasn't enough to save it. It's very dated and there is no auto save feature and if you go 30 minutes or any amount of time through the game without finding a statue and saving and die, you lose all that progress. You HAVE to use a statue to save as well. There are too few save statues and if you even forget and you progress for over an hour and die you'll find yourself having to do all that over again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198995226797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1676127611}
review:
For keyboard and mouse: Space key is A, Tab key is X, Esc key is the Y button, and F is B. The Enter key brings up options menu like game audio ect. Backspace brings up the monsters, items and Notes area. Down arrow key brings up ability items like the shield where you can use it, using tab. Haven't figured out an easier way to use the shield so you kind of just have to have good timing, or you know, have a controller lol. 

I played this on PlayStation 2 when I was a kid. Never beat it though so can't wait to do that now. or maybe after I get a controller.

PS. my friend bought me this game :3

author: {'steamid': '76561198041323259', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1025, 'last_played': 1671221042}
review:
I didn't play Sphinx back when it first came out, so I don't really hold any sense of nostalgia for it. Though I think anyone who has ever played a PS2 era action platformer or some of the earlier 3D Zelda games, will appreciate it.

I think there are better versions of the type of game it is - both from back when it first released (though that could be the nostalgia goggles speaking) and more recently - but it's definitely worth a play through for anyone who loves the era/genre and wants to see what they missed the first time round (like me!)

Plays well on the Steam Deck, though I did get a few audio glitches after waking up the Deck until I restarted.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072266312', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1003, 'last_played': 1669342134}
review:
The Legend of Mummy: A Sphinx to the Early Aughties

Well, it's finally done. This game has been itching the back of my skull ever since I lost my PS2 copy without completing it way back in the day. Now that I've finally scratched the itch, I'm pretty much satisfied. It's a good-but-not-great Zelda clone with top-notch graphics for the time, decent gameplay and progression with lots of room for improvement, and spectacular sound and art design.

I give this a tenuous recommendation. Zelda does this style of game much better, and there are a countless amount of good copycats of the top-down Zelda game style, but there's a good chance this might be the best 3D Zelda clone, as it's the only one I can think of. So it's worth it if you want to know what a fairly advanced Zelda is like without having to buy a 3DS or a Switch, or just want to explore an unusual game world that looks and sounds fantastic, in which case, I'm not sure why you're reading this far, you've already been sold on it.

review: A wonderful hidden gem from the PS2 era.  I never played it back then but am glad I finally got around to it.  Not only is the game itself a great example of a 3d puzzle platformer from the era, the PC conversion deserves praise as well.  It's clear in the five years since the initial "remastered" release the sole developer has been hard at work continuing to improve and optimize this 20 years old game for modern audiences.  Exceptional stuff here and well worth the asking price of $15 and a no-brainer when on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012591961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1963, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1963, 'last_played': 1663307377}
review:
Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy is a unique beast. It is a product of it's time, in both good and bad ways. 

Originally released back in 2003 for the PS2, Xbox and Gamecube, it seems to have all the trappings of a genre game from the early 2000s. Yet, these comparative examples to other games are mostly surface level, and why there is only a handful of games today that feel like Sphinx. Today, budgetary concerns impede the developer's freedom to use their imagination more than ever before. In the PS2 era, this risk was mitigated, which allowed more creative risk to be taken.

Set in mythological Egypt, the game follows not only titular hero Sphinx, but also the mummy Tutankhamen. Sphinx is tasked with breaking the curse that is ravishing the lands, so that he might stop the main villain Set. He'll travel to the city of Abydos, the land of Heliopolis, and more. All of these areas are sprawling with interconnected zones, dungeons, NPCs, sidequests, and collectibles. When in control of Sphinx, you have a simple sword to fight monsters and an energy shield to block projectiles; all other items are for puzzles and progression, or collecting monsters. 

At various intervals in the story you will come across Canopic Vases which hold part of Tutankhamen's soul, which magically teleport to him. The undead mummy, being held in Set's tower, gets his own moments to shine. The Tutankhamen segments are a unique juxtaposition from controlling Sphinx, for there is no combat involved. The game turns into a straight up puzzle platformer which consists of exploring the tower to find important stolen jewels, upgrades, and unique currency to send to Sphinx. The puzzles in these segments start simple but by the end of the game are pretty devious in their complexity. At various places you can find ways to light the mummy on fire, electrocute him, turn him into a flying dragon, etc. All of these are used to alter the environment to get to your end goal, but sometimes the environment will get in your way as well. You can't get through watery areas if you are on fire, or if you are electric. Late in the game you even come across ways to split the mummy into three, which you need to swap between to help solve large puzzles. They're good cerebral moments in the game, offering a nice of accomplishment when you solve the problems at hand. 

The synergy between segments, both in how it progresses gameplay and narrative, while offering refreshing changes of pace is brilliant. On top of that, they both add to the lore of this mythological setting in a way that culminates in a satisfactory way. You don't see many games that explore mythologies of the world in such imaginative ways, that also try to have a serious story in the end.

Now for the negative aspect that comes with games of the early 2000s: the controls. While mostly serviceable, due to the remaster, enough jank is apparent that it needs to be talked about.

Fighting an enemy can be a chore when they are running around you and the camera doesn't know how to adjust properly, or when it literally gets stuck on objects. This is made even worse when you try to collect rare monsters, which is further exacerbated when there are many on screen at once; when three or more enemies are attacking you at once the game simply sucks.  Using the blowpipe with a controller is a pain, as the sensitivity and deadzone makes it too much of a nuisance. For certain situations I had to switch to mouse control, which forced me to turn invert controls on every time: if invert was off, pointing the mouse up would actually move it down. Other issues crop up here and there, like grabbing ziplines and ledges when you know you should, but it's not too bad.  Lastly, all the bosses are quite frankly, awful.

The positive elements of the game really make the negatives easy to bear. The imaginative setting and story, diversity in design, and overall vibes culminate in something that is something to behold. The closest example to Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy is Beyond Good & Evil, which ironically came out the same year. And if you can appreciate all that, this game is a 100% recommendation.

review:
Ein absolut packendes Spiel aus der Nostalgie-Schublade. Es macht Spaß und ist teilweise sogar sehr anspruchsvoll.
Mit Zelda gehört es zu meinen absoluten Favoriten. Ich kann es jedem nur ans Herz legen, egal ob Kind oder Erwachsener. Schöne fesselnde Story, actiongeladene Sequenzen und eine für damals hervorragende World und Grafik. (immer noch sehr schön anzusehen)
Lasst euch drauf ein, ihr werdet es nicht bereuen!

author: {'steamid': '76561198159169396', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1849, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1849, 'last_played': 1547092405}
review:
You know growing up on the PS2 I had a lot of great games that I loved to play like Sly Cooper, Ty the Tasmanian Tiger, and this game, Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy. This game by far is one of the games that will get you giddy and nostalgic for many reasons such as the art, characters, scenery, the little games you play, and the lore. Who doesn't love a good game about certain gods from Egypt combined with the story on one of the Egyptian Kings that you read about in school. 

I highly recommend anyone and everyone to play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198377273338', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 859, 'last_played': 1528495941}
review:
Porting fatto molto bene che gira in modo liscio e tranquillo, ottimo!

Questo è un gioco che ha fatto parte della mia infanzia che all'epoca avevo abbandonato in quanto non riuscivo a superare un determinato punto. E' stato fantastico una volta ripreso su PC poter superare tale enigma e poter giungere al finale, anch'esso azzeccato e soddisfacente. Da quest'ultimo ho sempre sperato tuttavia in un secondo capitolo, ma credo che non ne vedremo mai la luce! :'(

Detto questo ho notato con piacere come il gioco, con il suo gameplay, non sia invecchiato affatto male, anzi!
E' stato molto divertente e stimolante riprendere un titolo di questo genere con tutti i suoi enigmi a tema egizio in cui dovremo superare ostacoli, intrappolare mostri e progredire con la scoperta dei piani del villain. Fantastico anche dopo quasi 20 anni!

CONSIGLIATO!

review: This game is absolutely a great buy from amongst its era! It's a fun throwback with these graphics and, yes, even the slightly clunky controls of that era as well. Combat is fairly simple. It's fun going through the environmental puzzles and seeing the strange creatures both friendly and enemies. You also get a good mix of gameplay between Sphinx and the Mummy (King Tut). There are lots of side quests, great maps to explore, and I creepy teleportation system lol. Get it, you'll enjoy it if you're open to games of that era.

review: A fun semi-action but mostly platform / puzzler from back in the day. This is a solid remaster, and I'd add the Shadow of Set mod for some new content if you had played it previously. Only downside is I experienced very frequent crashes, seemingly at random. Usually 2-3 per play session, so would recommend saving often but just being aware of that coming in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024753734', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 238, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1639773027}
review: This game sucks major DONG! The story is bare bones and uninteresting. It isn't worth paying attention. You switch between two characters Sphinx and Mummy. Sphinx can fight but combat in this dog sh*t game is terrible. You only have 1 attack so you just spam that. Also, combat is minimal. I played this garbage for 3 hours, and I think only 20 minutes of that time I was fighting with an enemy. If you count smashing vases as action then we can increase that time. Mummy only solves puzzles which involves getting burned, electrocuted, or flattened, and you use those same gimmicks every level which gets old pretty quickly. The game throws puzzle after puzzle in your way. You go to place and there is a locked door, you try another place and there's an item you need to find, you try another place and the list goes on like that. Enough with this bullsh*t already. A more straight-forward approach could have been 10 times better. The game throws you in a large area with no sense of direction at all and expects you to find the necessary items and progress without any help at all. Trying to find a small collectible in the corner of a large and multi segmental zone is a pain the as*! Without reading a walkthrough, don't even try to play this game. The platforming is bad because this game has one of the worst cameras ever. It is hard to judge distances, and sometimes your guy won't grab a ledge for no reason. There is also no voice acting, and the levels aren't very interesting. Compare this doney t*rd to Jak & Daxter 2 which is released in 2003 and it fails in every department. Jak & Daxter 2 is how an action platformer game should be. Good voice acting. Decent action mixed with platforming and an engaging story. The sphinx hasn't got a redeeming quality at all. After playing for 3 hours, I stopped because I'm bored to death.

author: {'steamid': '76561198805663406', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1637198224}
review: I remember back in 2003 sitting on my Grandfathers bed watching my brother and sister play this game until I could wrap my head around how the Ps2 worked and played it myself. After so many years I forgot about this game but once I saw it was on the steam store I think a spike of serotonin hit me like a train. This game holds so many heartfelt memories within me that just launching the game and hearing the title screen music made me laugh with joy. I was so happy revisiting this game, I dont think I can ever hate it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073923233', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1207, 'last_played': 1654783946}
review: A very unique puzzle platformer from the golden era of consoles. The Egyptian setting is very well presented and is fun to explore. I am glad to play this port finally on PC with glorious 60 fps visuals. I wholeheartedly recommend this game to people who love old games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999199281', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 2623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1321, 'last_played': 1708712364}
review:
Ok, so I basically finished the game in three days, I was really invested. 

First of, this game is heavily puzzle based, which is something I'm perfectly alright with. However, there are some puzzles that can go nope themselves (I'm looking at you, King Sarcophagus torches).
I also can see why people are always asking for a second game, but I won't say anything to not let any spoilers Set in this review.

In any case, I love the game, I've been wanting to play it for years and I was finally able to. Like I said in some screenshots, the background artwork is amazing, and gives me that feeling of wanting to explore and unlock more stuff to see new places. Also that super specific prophecy, I won't lie, I chuckled a bit while reading it. It felt like Osiris made a shop list instead of a prophecy: "Alright, I'll need this specific individual to help me, no other one, just this one, so help me if someone else tries".

Anyway, if the devs decide to make a second game, I'll be there to play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199169006880', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 950, 'last_played': 1632016270}

author: {'steamid': '76561197969677701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 2193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2193, 'last_played': 1631389797}
review:
I've never heard of this game until recently through Nitro Rad and a friend but I'm sure glad I did because this was the most enjoyable 3D platformer I've played in quite some time.

Something you should know if you ever decide to give this game a shot - there is no autosaving\checkpoints. If you die, you're sent to the last save you made, which can only be done in specific save points. No worries, though, as it's not at all as intimidating as it sounds. There are savepoints pretty regularly and you really get used to saving very quickly. You also don't die so easily. Most of your deaths, if you'll even have any, will come from trial and error of not knowing certain enemies\boss fights beforehand. Most cutscenes are skippable so trying again is as effortless as it can be. Just maintain the habit of going back to a nearby savepoint if you feel like you're dangerously close to death.

There's something oddly comfy about the Egyptian setting in videogames as made in games like Serious Sam TFE, Crash Bandicoot: Warped and others, in a colorful way that's very eyecatching. Sphinx pulls that aesthetic off beautifully.

The puzzles are very fun and interesting, with very few exceptions. The progression is satisfying, which also feeds to how great exploration feels. Sphinx does a great job at making it easy to figure out where you have to go and what you have to do but without flat out handing you the solution.

I'm glad this game has been brought back and updated. The sheer amount of work that has gone into this re-release is incredible. You need only look at the game's patch notes dating back to 2017 to see that this is an effort worth commending. Hopefully more people will discover and enjoy this game as I have, but for now, hats off to anyone responsible for this re-release, and the people who originally developed it, of course.

author: {'steamid': '76561199076637002', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 703, 'last_played': 1704084989}
review:
Another great game from the PS2 era. Its has a simple plot but the world manages to draw you in. The puzzle aspect can get a bit tedious at times but it is still a fun adventure game to get lost in. Not many games have such a rich and fun take on Egyptian lore too. The music is amazing as well.

I bought this when it was still had a few bugs and only had keyboard support. Jump several months later, bugs are fixed and it has full controller support like it should!

author: {'steamid': '76561198115801653', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 989, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1631098697}
review: Played this game when i father came home from a few years of working abroad PS2 was the first console i had, i was 3rd or 4th grade at that time, i cant get past the start of the game (were monster suppose to spew you) now bought it and playing it again and try to finish what i started.. its embarrasing..

author: {'steamid': '76561198846160542', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1627787028}
review:
Un juego tipo Zelda con temática egipcia fuertemente occidentalizada, y con muchos puzzles para resolver en el camino. Gráficos 3D un poco anticuados pero no feos, con un estilo afín al cartoon occidental. Si te atrae la combinación, pruébalo.
Como todos los juegos de ese tipo, puede ponerse muy aburrido si te alejas de él un tiempo y vuelves luego sin saber ya qué hacer; así que mejor juégalo de un tirón.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077906644', 'num_games_owned': 1259, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 801, 'last_played': 1627174242}
review:
I had this on PS2. It feels like AGES ago since I've played through this game, and playing it once again brings back so much nostalgia. This game is wonderful, the music will get stuck in your head, and the game itself is pretty engaging.

On the other hand, ever since I purchased this game I've noticed one glaring flaw with this PC version... The UI and text doesn't scale well with higher resolutions. I play on a 4K monitor, and everything is TINY. It's not unplayable, by any means, everything is still readable and the graphics scale well, but I find that to be a major issue.

Point is, HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.
developer_response:
You are right, this has been something I have been meaning to fix for a while. There is a patch in the works that will bring proper HiDPI scaling, among other things.

This feature in particular is done, the update itself needs a few tweaks. Glad that you enjoyed the game, it deserves all these modern niceties.

Thanks for the honest review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198259823607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1046, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 859, 'last_played': 1623369891}
review:
I started this game as a kid and never got the chance to finish the first level so I was delighted to find it on steam! Playing it now I realized its basically egyptian Legend of Zelda and I love that about it, it gives off Ocarina of Time vibes with creepy ominous whispers in dungeons contrasted with fun happy music in the sun on the beach. There are games to be played and prizes to be won in the city and on the beaches, a museum to collect for using a Pokemon-like creature capture system (which is also used to solve some puzzles with creatures that have special abilities) and tonnes of clay pots to smash and hanging lanterns to whack in exchange for a few coins. There are multiple worldspaces to explore using the zip-line, swimming, bird riding and sprint pad mechanics to get around with ease - and thats just the part where you play as Sphinx! There's a split story line (not unlike how GTA V's story works, just obviously more primitive) where you get to play as a mummy and explore the enemy's castle while solving fun puzzles that will 100% of the time require you to set yourself on fire. By the end of the mummy's level you will have collected a new ability for Sphinx to use so it blends well in terms of progression too. 

The only downside is the common issue of older games where they make you wait a lot, not a big deal to be honest I know I'm impatient but it does sometimes mess up the flow of the game's combat or platforming. Combat can be unforgiving and if you get cocky you'll pay for it, but it can also be rewarding when a creature/item/ability is used properly.

TL;DR
Overall a great game even now almost 20 years later, highly recommend if you enjoyed Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time or Majora's Mask. Music/Vibes - 10/10. Gameplay - 8/10. Egyptian cat man go brrrrrr

ALSO Y'ALL SHOULD BE PLAYING THIS IN COMPATIBILITY MODE FFS THATS WHY IT CRASHES ON YA

author: {'steamid': '76561197985654160', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 408, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1702220637}
review:
Bei dem Spiel springt man durch ein mysthisches Ägypten löst Rästel (Schalter schieben, dann passiert was). Die Grafik ist etwas in Jahre gekommen, aber geht noch als voll OK durch. Aber warum gibt es so überhaupt keine Sprachausgabe? Also auch kein sinnbefreites gebabbelt, welches die Textzeile wenigstens ein bisschen untermalt. So bewegen die Charaktere stumm ihre Lippen. Nur Horus grunzt mal kurz, wenn er den Schnabel aufmacht - und nervt dann auch noch voll. Die Steuerung kommt mir manchmal etwas schwammig vor, das ist ärgerlich, wenn man deswegen irgendwo runterfällt oder ein Seil verfehlt oder sonst was. Ich hab es ca. eine Stunde gespielt aber der Funke ist bei mir überhaupt nicht übergesprungen, ich fand es insgesamt etwas öde. Schade.

Hier der Link zu meinem "Angespielt"-Video:
https://youtu.be/iYDC0aV5WQw

author: {'steamid': '76561198078588334', 'num_games_owned': 1061, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 2046, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2046, 'last_played': 1623047528}
review:
It was definitely an experience. I really disliked the beginning, but about an hour in, it started getting good. The controls are a little jank, but da graphic look gud. Throughout my entire playthrough my game only crashed once.  There's a couple unintuitive puzzles thrown in like having to destroy the right pot. This game was definitely more good than bad. A lot more. Worth a buy!

Enjoyment Rating: 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198134331395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1623017527}
review:
To start off: I remember this game very well, it's nostalgic to be able to play again. 
One of the few games I started out playing and also one that got me into mythologies. 
There are parts that can be frustrating if your so used to modern games, especially the quick save function, but it's nice to be able to step back too what got me into games in the first place. I suggest anyone get this game, its easy to pick up and it's nice to enjoy "classic" games every now and again.

review: Very nostalgic, it sort of just throws you in with no explanation whatsoever, but the story is pretty decent. It's pretty much just an old game from the later end of the platformer era with wonky controls and tedious puzzles. All in all it's cartoonish and only vaguely based on Egyptian themes, but it's pretty fun. The lack of explanation is both mildly frustrating and satisfying at the same time because you really have to figure everything out for yourself.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982160366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 408, 'playtime_forever': 1687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1687, 'last_played': 1618596386}
review:
[h1][i] La momie [/i][/h1]
Sphinx propose une petite virée dans l'Égypte mythologique. L'histoire se centre sur le jeune Sphinx, qui se trouve plongé dans une lutte contre Seth, qui a lui même notamment transformé Toutânkhamon en momie. Sphinx va donc, au travers de ses aventures, tâcher d'aider son prochain, de contrecarrer les plans de Seth et d'essayer d'inverser la malédiction qui pèse sur le futur pharaon. 

Le jeu est une sorte d'action/aventure avec quelques éléments d'exploration. 
[b]Le jeu est séparé en deux parties :[/b]
[list] [*] les passages où l'on incarne Sphinx, le personnage principal. 
Ce dernier évolue entre deux zones principales, où certains passages se débloqueront au fur et à mesure de l'histoire et de son avancée. 
Son gameplay est lui même décomposé en plusieurs parties : l'exploration des zones, des mini jeux (tir, course d'obstacles...) et quêtes secondaires dont une sorte de Pokemon like, où il s'agira d'attraper tous les monstres que vous croiserez, les phases de puzzle et les phases de combats. 
Énigmes et combats plutôt bien pensées, avec notamment des combats de boss où il ne suffit pas juste de taper comme un sourd pour l'emporter. 
[*] et ceux où l'on incarne Toutânkhamon, uniquement dans des phases de puzzle, qui sont de manière générale plutôt intéressantes. [/list]

La quête principale alterne donc entre les deux personnages de manière assez fluide.
Les mécaniques ressemblent d'ailleurs beaucoup à Beyond Good and Evil, sur les différentes phases de gameplay.

En revanche, contrairement à ce dernier il a malheureusement quelques faiblesses dont :
[list] [*]la non possibilité de sauvegarder lorsqu'on le souhaite, et pas de checkpoints. La seule possibilité est donc d'aller manuellement devant des balises pour sauvegarder. Sur le principe, pourquoi pas ? Malheureusement, on se retrouve, notamment au début à risquer de recommencer des pans de 15-20 minutes de jeu pour une mauvaise chute, ou un combat à la c**. Alors qu'il aurait juste suffit de créer des checkpoints avant les combats, ou les boss, par exemple, pour résoudre le problème. 
[*] les sauvegardes sont d'ailleurs à l'ancienne avec un emplacement unique. Ce qui veut donc dire : pas de retour en arrière possible. Et forcément, dans ce type de jeu, le risque sans soluce est de passer à côté de certaines choses, notamment secondaires et donc tout  recommencer de zéro si vous vous en rendez compte après coup.
[*]des mécaniques parfois peu claires, notamment au début. 
Du type : un objet qui est censé exploser quelque chose en le déposant sur un pan de mur mais ça ne marche pas - mais en fait ça marche car il fallait décaler ledit objet de 10cm à gauche ; ou une quête qu'on vend comme secondaire - mais qui en fait est juste complètement déterminante pour la suite, puisqu'elle débloque un objet nécessaire pour avancer ; ou la capture des bestioles qui au départ n'est pas forcément super bien expliquée.

Il m'est donc arrivé plusieurs fois d'aller fureter sur le net pour aller comprendre des choses peu claires, là où ça ne m'est jamais arrivé dans Beyond.
[*]et un peu déçu de la fin, sans spoiler, globalement torché en 40 secondes chrono.[/list]

Cependant, je ne lui jette pas la pierre. Datant de 2003, il est juste assez fidèle à son époque dans ses mécaniques et ses faiblesses.

[b]Il reste donc une bonne expérience en termes de jeu d'aventures pour une vingtaine d'heures, avec une ambiance plutôt réussie, et graphiquement largement regardable de nos jours[/b]

[i]PS : et sinon l'acolyte de Seth ressemble à Tournevis dans Astérix et Cléopâtre, et je parle bien entendu du film d'animation.[/i]

[b][i]Plus de critiques ? ->[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/39925920] C'est ici ;)[/url][/i][/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198027038417', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1681573712}
review:
Note: I played (and beat) this game back on the original GameCube release, and still have my old copy. :)

Great adventure game with a lot of funny and quirky personality. This game has a lot of puzzles, but the puzzles are very well designed and honestly some really top tier puzzles in any video game. The game still looks beautiful despite being originally for the GameCube generation.

Highly recommend. Easily earns the currently $14.99 price tag (I'm surprised the price isn't higher).

Although I would like a sequel, this is one of those games that a sequel could be really bad if in the wrong hands. The overall design of the maps, puzzles, and varied mechanics just makes this game a joy to play... It isn't something you can slap together in a modern game engine without a lot of meticulous design.

Also Note: I did unfortunately run into the infamous "save glitch" back in the day. But even that didn't stop me from replaying the game from the beginning and finishing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996805558', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1614423567}
review:
Achtung: Dies ist ein reines Konsolenspiel. Nicht nur, dass im Spiel ausschließlich die Konsolensteuerung erklärt wird, auch die Menüführung ist vollkommen PC-untypisch. Es gibt einen gepinnten Diskussionsbeitrag der Entwickler, dass sie sich dieses Problems bewusst sind, wo eine Tastaturbelegung dokumentiert ist und wo das Versprechen steht, dass es bald verbessert werden soll. Aber dieser Beitrag ist von 2018, also ist aus dem Versprechen wohl nichts geworden.
Dass die Grafik von ~2008 ist, sah ich ja vorher und es hat mich nicht gestört. Aber für mich muss ein PC-Spiel ohne Controller spielbar sein und bei der Menüführung und den Optionen gewisse Standards einhalten. Das ist hier nicht der Fall, darum empfehle ich dieses Programm nicht weiter. Über das 'Spiel' an sich kann ich nichts sagen, es war ein uninformierter Blindkauf, die Videos und Bilder fand ich interessant genug.

author: {'steamid': '76561198829589351', 'num_games_owned': 528, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1606, 'last_played': 1614787264}
review: Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy! me gusta mucho este juego pero tengo un bug que no me deja pasar de nivel y no creo que lo arreglen no se si reiniciando el juego se arregle.Que por cierto ya estoy muy lejos  y no creo que creo que los creadores del juego lo arreglen ya que es un juego viejo.
developer_response:
Hola, soy el desarrollador de la versión de PC.

Si abres un hilo en el foro de Steam y nos das más detalles sobre el punto en el que el juego se queda atascado lo miraré e intentaré arreglarlo. Entiendo castellano e inglés, así que si es por eso no hay problema ninguno. Ya me contarás.

A ver si lo solucionamos, porque seguimos actualizando y mejorándolo de vez en cuando.

review:
Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy
---------------------------------------
Nostalgia is a huge factor to why i bought this game.
Loved it on the ps2. Still love to play this great oldschool platformer.
A great story, great characters and awesome game design.
Clearly inspired by the legend of zelda. And it takes its inspiration to hearth.
This is a great game that will give you a solid adventure.

Enjoy the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030250363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1613435968}
review: The save system of this game is absolute garbage. Even the tutorial area has too many ways to take damage and not enough ways to heal, so it's easy to lose 10-20 minutes of progress over a single difficult jump. At this point I don't really care how good or bad the rest of the game is, this simply isn't worth putting up with.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977205782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 1605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1605, 'last_played': 1613245986}
review:
Keeping in mind this a HD port of a 2003 PS2 game, this is a very good Zelda-like game. It does have some control problems and I wish that the platforming mechanics were tighter. The ending is a bit abrupt as there was a sequel intended, but never made.

But, this is very clearly inspired by Ocarina of Time. It's not as good as OOT by any means. But, for a Zelda-like on PC where there are hardly any Zelda-likes available, this is a very competent game. (I'm also a sucker for the ancient Egypt aesthetic, so it gets points for that too). Easy recommend for the $4 sale price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088354334', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1758, 'last_played': 1675584967}
review:
I can recall it, my eighth birthday in 2004. I didn't get much in terms of new video games but I did get something that made me feel like a big kid, three Gamecube games rated T for Teen. Star Wars Rogue Squadron 3: Rebel Strike, 007 - Agent Under Fire, and of course, Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy. I alternated between the 3 a lot that day and the following ones, giving them their turns in the purple lunchbox out of hype before eventually doing extended sessions with them. I can't recall the events after that, but I know I sat down and jammed with Sphinx for quite awhile eventually. Subsequently completing it for the first time, I thoroughly enjoyed it (though I was stuck at the Uruk Temple for quite a bit trying to figure out the puzzle and hating that were no save points inside so interruptions would cause a progress reset but that didn't hurt my opinion at all) and had replayed it a few times, picking up a few new things along the way, even filling out the museum too. I'd watch the making of now and then and wonder where some of those other places were, being mesmerized by how much depth was here. I even encountered the old Mummy softlock if you saved your game and quit at the wrong time during the second sequence. (bummer)

Though time passes, you move on, discs get worn and torn, and emulation seems a bit out of the way at times, or you just forget. But I'd recall this game every now and then, and eventually I learn it was on Steam, actively supported and ripe for PC gaming. So of course I pounced on buying it when it was on sale for stupid cheap, as it would allow me to own it on a platform where I could play it easily. Looking at its small but heavily dedicated community was sure inspiring and I had played it for a bit before other things sapped my time, outside of an arbitrary bug I had spoken to a developer to the game was the same, but better.

It's Sphinx, just as I remember it. No clutter, supported actively and given a few modern things like resolution improvement and some settings that are tweakable for PC (mods included). If you're interested in a Zelda-like with an Egyptian-mythos flavor, then this will suit you, if you're a returning player, see if it lives up to how you remember it.

To people new to Sphinx: keep in mind this game is from 2003, ported to modern hardware and maintained as such. Aside from the resolution increase/options, cut content being moddable into the PC version (among other mods) and the options given to the PC version, the game is presented as it was back in '03. If you're pining for features you've been spoiled with from larger companies/franchises or from much later video games, this probably won't stomach well for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029215414', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1611115187}
review:
A bit of a long review, so TLDR

Pros - Fun world and story, decent platforming and combat challenges, a lot of fun and interesting abilities to unlock, the best mummy in all of video games, genuinely good puzzles for said mummy gameplay.  Great soundtrack.  Cheap as dirt and runs on anything.

Cons - old school camera, old school combat, old school save system.  No voice acting.  It ends on a cliffhanger that will almost certainly never be followed up on.

Never knew about this game as a kid, so I have no nostalgia for this game, and with that I can confidently say this one is a hidden gem.  The game, as is, clearly shows its age and budget, and has some issues that persisted into this port, but it plays to its strengths and is actually pretty ambitious.

I'll get my little nitpicks out of the way first, which really all come down to some quality of life improvements that would be appreciated.  The camera is a bit clunky and has a tendency to run up and get stuck on walls, making platforming in tighter spaces hard to judge, especially with a lack of a shadow to show where you're landing.  The camera is also a bit of a problem when trying to catch monsters, as the camera locks up, and that now controls your capture bug.  While it's nice to be able to move the bug and yourself at the same time in theory, in practice, it makes capturing something mid combat incredibly risky, especially with hard hitting enemies.  Speaking of, Sphinx himself doesn't seem to have much, if any iframes when taking damage, meaning against foes that make multiple attacks at a time, if you get hit, you can take a lot of damage very quickly, leading to a game over and sending you back to your last save.  The save points are also often a bit out of the way in dungeons, and regularly having to save after almost any progress in a dungeon is tedious, and neglecting to do so can loose a lot of progress if you then die later on.  Being able to save from the pause menu would be a very welcome addition.

Also no voice acting, but the game's not dead silent and it clearly wasn't really in the original's budget, so that hardly a nitpick.

Now onto the good shit.  Everything else about this game is incredibly solid.  Combat is fun, the game overall provides a decent challenge, it's surprisingly not hand-holdy, and the soundscape is great.  But the best part of this game are the few Mummy sections.  Several times through the game, you get to play a puzzle section as a charming mummy man.  Being an undead being, Prince Tut cannot be harmed, and the developers run wild this concept.  As the mummy, you ignite, electrify, squish, and chop yourself to get past several obstacles, and it makes for some incredibly unique and fun puzzles.  Honestly, this is something I wish we had more of, and deserves to be its own standalone game, even moreso when with every completed segment, Tut puts on a big, dopey smile, gives a thumbs up to the camera, and the most charming "Yeah!" in all of video games, before sauntering away.  For how good the character and puzzles are, its almost a negative how little time you get to spend play as Tut.

So, yeah.  This game deserved way more recognition than it got back when it released, and it's a damn shame it never got a follow up with how much promise and talent this game's mechanics and setting has.  Maybe someday someone will make the mummy puzzle game of my dreams, and the more people that buy this game, the more likely that is to happen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198859937967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 2760, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1034, 'last_played': 1633542672}
review:
One of my top favorite games since I was a kid. 
Was never able to beat it and then never able to find it again in stores after I lost it.
Was just about to go into the final stage of the game when I decided to do some research on mods. 
Came across Sphinx and the Shadow of Set. 
Deleted my 17 hour save file and am starting a new game with this mod to complete it the RIGHT way. With the original content. 
I love this game that much that I refuse to beat this without the restored levels. The way this game was meant to be! If you know what's good about gaming you will pick up this classic and if you have the respect, I recommend you installing that mod and supporting these talented creators!
WE NEED A REMASTERED EDITION OF THIS GAME WITH THE ALL OF THE ORIGINAL CONTENT!

author: {'steamid': '76561198196994402', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1052, 'last_played': 1605965832}
review:
[h1]Худшее управление из всех, что я видел.[/h1]
Сражаешься не с врагами, а с управлением...
Если освоитесь и научитесь попадать по монстрам, то попадания часто не будут засчитываться, т.к. тестировать боевую систему разработчики похоже и не думали.
Сохраниться где угодно нельзя и местами придётся разбираться с врагами пачками, а возврат и посещение мест сохранения респаунит убитых.
Единственное, что я могу однозначно рекомендовать, если Вы всё-таки купите сию сырость - [u]обязательно используйте контроллер-геймпад.[/u]

author: {'steamid': '76561198052941330', 'num_games_owned': 1051, 'num_reviews': 472, 'playtime_forever': 1606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1606, 'last_played': 1605197837}
review: Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy is a great game, but it has some issues. First of all, there's barely any story in this game. It's very light. Gameplay wise, however, it's a lot of fun. Sphinx has Zelda-like gameplay, and the puzzles are a ton of fun. I would say that's the main reason for getting this game. The graphics are also great. I was very impressed many times, and that's especially impressive, considering how old the game is. I don't know if they upgraded the graphics a lot for the PC version or what, but it does look good. Music is also decent, even though some of it is rather generic. Overall, there's a lot of content in this game, so I would definitely say it's worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198206440344', 'num_games_owned': 96, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1534, 'last_played': 1608368676}
review: I have heard of Sphinx and the Cursed Mummy before but could never get a hold of it for my PS2 coz of where I live. Nevertheless it was an amazing game, providing an alternate storytelling of the Egyptian Mythology, with tight controls, two diverse playstyles coming from two characters: Sphinx's part being more platforming and exploration focused with a really nice semi-open world (no minimap tho but it never bothered me rather its welcome), diverse monsters and enemies, and unique (the blowpipe) yet classic simple combat albeit without a proper dodge skill; and for Tut aka our favorite Mummy, the puzzle mechanics were a legit treat. The Mummy's part is all bout puzzle solving at its core with no combat. Puzzles werent too hard but to me always ever enjoyable. Sphinx is all bout confidence and courage which his (overtly) smug expression clearly conveys, but I found Tutankhamen, from his careless clumsy nature, to the amazing goofy walk cycle, and his facial expressions, to be all much more expressive compared to Sphinx, till the end. I did wish Sphinx and Tut would have a moment as they finally meet but oh well. Controlling the character, timing jumps and all seemed a bit floaty at first, but once you get used to it it will be all natural and fun. Amazing game and a must play platformer!

review: One of my first and favorite PS2/XBOX games, and I'm still absolutely depressed it never got a sequel!! Completely worth the nostalgia kick, but just a heads up that some people may experience a lack of environmental effects depending on their computer/hardware (I'm personally playing on a mac), such as full view of flames and water effects at a certain closeness. I personally took it as a challenge, but some people might find it game breaking. That aside, still as fun and beautiful as I remember!

author: {'steamid': '76561198122299982', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1975, 'last_played': 1601344039}
review:
Thoroughly enjoyed this game! I originally had it on PS2 but did not play very much of it. I believe it was because I did not understand the game well when I was younger so I could not appreciate the puzzles. I do appreciate the art and aesthetics of this game and what it was trying to convey. A platforming and puzzle game that is worth the time put into it. I love the Mummy sections (except that pentagram puzzle). The Mummy has so much character and then with each special ability he gets there is a different music track for it. There are so many great ideas in this game that I wish I saw in more games. I am kind of disappointed this game didn’t get a sequel and that not many people probably know about this game in general. 
I must admit there are some wonky game mechanics that could be improved or just little changes that would make it over all more enjoyable. For example, when selling monsters in the Monster Shop to be able to sell multiple instead of one at a time and going through all the dialogue every time. Also, when doing some of the time trials on Heliopolis it would have been better to see the timer or some indication on how you were doing. One has to keep in mind that this was originally a PS2 game released in 2003 so there is no autosave and you cannot rotate saves. 
The combat can be a little frustrating since there is no lock on. You really have to work the camera in this game at points. The camera does not go through objects/walls either so that can hinder you in a couple of places, but the game is playable and completable.
Overall, I really liked this game. I recently finished it so I probably won’t replay it anytime soon, but I believe I’ll play it again within a year.

author: {'steamid': '76561199022955773', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1599869580}
review: This was my favorite game on PS2, and also one of my childhood's fondest memories. My PS2 has died a long time ago and I was no longer able to play for years. So thank you very much to the wonderful team and developers who made it possible for me to play again! Of course, the controls are a lot different, and they take some time to get used to, but overall the game is really worth it for those who have grown up with that game and love it. The game has aged surprisingly well and the graphics are awesome despite it being a port for the original game which was released nearly 20 years ago. I'm actually having a lot of fun, just like the first time I played it. Highly recommend!

review: childhood favorite

author: {'steamid': '76561198167173649', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 1067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1000, 'last_played': 1598648793}
review:
+ Length
+ Collectables
+ Helpful developers


Very solid game, fair balance of platforming and puzzles to keep it from growing stale. 
I really liked how they take advantage of their characters to certain puzzles and ideas and make it seem natural.
I thought I would hate the mummy sections but they have some nice thought into them and the Mummy has some charming animations which makes him one of my favourites.

Any issues I have had so far the developers are still active on the forums to help out and try to help you with so kudos to them for still caring about the game! Would love to see a squeal to this because much more could easily be added/done.


I am disappointed some characters just disappear from the story and never given a reason why, you either assume they were killed or just became so unimportant they had no use for them. Kinda sucks for those wanting closure on some of them.



- Music often cuts out
- A few bugs/glitches
- Missable achievements


Music will often disappear, making me have to exit the game completely and reboot it for it to come back, not really stopping you from playing but can take you out of the game to near nothing but the sound effects. Some sound effects will also overlap each other constantly and not go away which is more annoying than no music, again you need to reopen the game to get rid of this or mute the sounds.

I did run into a bug/glitch or two that either stopped me progressing or just killed me, one being after a cutscene, something that was meant to appear did not, lucky a save point was just used so nothing really lost but you cannot skip the cutscenes so this can be an issue.
Another bug caused me to be unable to swim underwater but be stuck at the bottom of the water (this was due to somehow I slammed down into the water, slide across the wall and it put me in my walking animation) This caused me to game-over so bewarned to save often to not lose a good chunk of progress.

Lastly, around 5 achievements are missable, 2 are at the start of the game so not too hard to get but one you can easily miss without a guide and I can see this being annoying having to restart from scratch and redo everything just because you missed one thing you couldn't return to in the story.


Overall it is a solid game but you have to remember it is a 2003 game and I say it has aged well, the models still look ok and the environments look lovely to just run around in.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960291586', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1598466212}
review:
The game is starting poorly but becomes quite interesting quickly.
The two characters are different and fun to play, the world is nice to explore and the puzzles are quite interesting.
Everything is a bit rough of course, it's an old game. The camera can especially be frustrating, especially during the (short) platform sections.
But I can't recommend this game because of its save system. The save points can be very long to reach and losing your last live means that you return to your previous save.
This is maybe how it worked at the time but in our days it feels really dumb. I finished a 45 minutes dungeon  without any save point accessible, then went back to the world and died by drowning, just because I wanted to explore. I was very sad to respawn at the beginning of the dungeon that I just finished, having to do all over again. Needless to say, I stopped playing on the spot.
So this game does not respect the player's time, so that's a major no-go for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144580151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1710200009}
review:
This has been an all time favorite game of mine since I first played it on the Playstation 2.  The graphics at the time were pretty to look at, the gameplay was overall fun, the story was engaging enough and easy to follow, and overall I just greatly enjoyed it.  My only critique against it was that the ending was pretty bad and seemed like it was going to try setting up for a sequel that never ended up happening.

The Steam/GoG version emphasizes what I like about the game.  The soundtrack is still pretty awesome to listen to, the gameplay is still overall fine (though I do dislike that it was built more around a controller...unfortunately you learn trying to play with a keyboard that the game doesn't feel right without a controller), and on top of that the HD sharpening and whatnot just really shows how well the graphics still hold up in my personal opinion.  They didn't go for complete realism, but they also didn't go the cell shaded route and went more for an in the middle cartoon-ish CG type of look, and it actually still looks pretty good today.  Not "Wow" worthy compared to newer games, but I'd still place it in the same category as, say, Kingdom Hearts when the 1.5 HD collection came out.  The graphics still look phenomenal even compared to games from the PS3-X360 era, and it easily looks like it could have been released around that time as opposed to the PS2 days.  Hell, this could release on the newer consoles and I'd be okay, because it looks like a remaster that could easily do well on the PS4 or Xone.

But this is also because the game just runs so much smoother as well, which lets everything show itself off without the stutter and sluggishness from a lower framerate which the PS2 was known for (though it looked and played fine on the Gamecube).  I always love seeing an older game I remember being shown more of its potential in looks alone when they're able to get into that higher FPS and make everything run that much smoother.

Overall...is part of my excitement for this game nostalgia? Absolutely.  It brings back some great memories of games from back in the day when they first released, like Okami (another game that got a great HD remake), Sly Cooper, and various others.  But it's really hard to deny that the game still looks, sounds and plays overall pretty great today.
